questions.text: Simple scratching over skin relieves Itching because
questions.solution:
• Antihistaminics are primarily effective in reducing pruritis associated with an allergic reaction, as Histamine is involved in allergic reaction.
  • Itching sensations are carried via type C fibres. Type B fibers carry autonomic fibers and is not stimulated or inhibited by scratching over skin.
  • Simple scratching relieves itching because it activates large, fast-conducting afferents that gate transmission in the dorsal horn in a manner analogous to the inhibition of pain by stimulation of similar afferents. In a mouse model exhibiting scratching behavior in response to activation of PAR-2, treatment with a B2 receptor antagonist reduced the scratching behavior. B2 receptor antagonists may be a useful therapy for treating pruriginous conditions.
  • Bradykinin is a vasodilator substance which is increased with scratching over skin but do not relieves itching.

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 24th Edition Ch 8 Pg: 160

questions.text: During prolonged fasting, rate of gluconeogenesis is determined by:
questions.solution:
• Gluconeogenesis is the process of synthesizing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, and it primarily takes place in the liver (and to a lesser extent in the kidneys). During prolonged fasting, when dietary glucose is not available, gluconeogenesis becomes essential for maintaining blood glucose levels.
  • Alanine, an amino acid, plays a pivotal role in this process through the Alanine Cycle:
  • Muscle Protein Breakdown: During fasting, muscle proteins are broken down into amino acids. Alanine is released from muscle tissue into the bloodstream.
  • Transport to the Liver: Alanine is transported to the liver, where it serves as a significant substrate for gluconeogenesis.
  • Gluconeogenesis: In the liver, alanine is converted into pyruvate via transamination. Pyruvate is a key intermediate in gluconeogenesis. It can be converted into glucose, which is then released into the bloodstream to maintain blood glucose levels.
  • Urea Cycle: The nitrogen from alanine is used in the urea cycle to form urea, which is excreted by the kidneys. This process helps to eliminate excess nitrogen from the body.
  • Why Not the Other Options?
  • A. Essential Fatty Acid in liver: Essential fatty acids are crucial for many functions in the body, but they are not direct determinants of the rate of gluconeogenesis. They are more involved in the production of ketone bodies during fasting.
  • C. Decreased cGMP: Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) is a secondary messenger involved in many physiological processes. Its role is not directly related to the regulation of gluconeogenesis during fasting.
  • D. ADP in liver: Adenosine diphosphate (ADP) is involved in cellular energy transfer. While energy status (ATP/ADP levels) in the liver can affect metabolic pathways, alanine availability is more directly related to the rate of gluconeogenesis during fasting.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition - Page 185-186

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the physician with complaints of severe muscle aches, tenderness in muscles and fatigue for 3-4 days. He has history of hyperlipidemia for which he was taking lovastatin. Last week he was diagnosed with atypical pneumonia and treated with clarithromycin. Serum studies show an elevated creatinine kinase concentration. This patient's current symptoms are most likely caused by inhibition of which of the following hepatic enzymes?
questions.solution:
The risk of statin-induced toxic myopathy increases with the addition of cytochrome CYP3A4 inhibitors, which include the macrolides clarithromycin and erythromycin (not azithromycin).

Other common CYP3A4 inhibitors include amiodarone, antifungals (azoles, e.g., itraconazole), several anti-HIV medications, histamine H2 receptor antagonists (e.g., cimetidine), and grapefruit juice.

Lipophilic statins such as simvastatin, atorvastatin, and lovastatin have a higher propensity to cause myopathy than do hydrophilic agents (pravastatin, rosuvastatin), which are not significantly metabolized by CYP3A4.

CYP3A4 is involved in the metabolism of > 60% of drugs, and inhibition of this enzyme can lead to an increased risk of drug toxicity

  • Mnemonic

Enzyme inhibitors [ Virat Kohli Can't Call Every Indians]

Valproate

Ketoconazole

Cimetidine

Ciprofloxacin/Clarithromycin

Erythromycin

INH

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 30

questions.text: Five clean practices under strategies for elimination of neonatal tetanus include all except
questions.solution:
a. Clean surface for delivery: This is crucial to prevent contamination of the newborn with bacteria or spores that could lead to tetanus infection. Ensuring the delivery surface is clean reduces the risk of introducing harmful pathogens.

b. Clean hand: Healthcare providers must maintain clean hands to prevent the transmission of bacteria or spores from their hands to the newborn during delivery or handling. Hand hygiene is a fundamental practice in preventing the spread of infections.

c. New blade for cutting cord: Using a new, sterile blade to cut the umbilical cord minimizes the risk of tetanus spores entering the newborn's bloodstream through the open wound created during cord cutting. Sterilized equipment helps prevent contamination and reduces the risk of NT transmission.

d. Clean airway: While maintaining a clear airway is essential for newborns to ensure proper breathing, it is not directly linked to preventing neonatal tetanus. NT primarily occurs due to contamination of wounds, such as the umbilical cord stump, with tetanus spores. While keeping the airway clear is undoubtedly important for overall neonatal health, it's not a specific strategy for preventing NT.

questions.text: A 10 year old boy presented with a swelling of the jaw. Bone marrow aspiration shown. On further evaluation, the patient is detected to have translocation (8,14). What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Burkitt's lymphoma

  • Highly aggressive B cell neoplasm
  • can present in one of three distinct clinical forms:
    • Endemic
    • Sporadic
    • Immunodeficiency associated
  • Patients with BL present with rapidly growing tumor masses
  • Endemic form
    • a jaw or facial bone tumor that spreads to extranodal sites
    • ovary, testis, kidney, breast, and especially the bone marrow & meninges
  • Sporadic form
    • abdominal presentation most often with massive disease.
  • Immunodeficiency related
    • cases more often involve lymph nodes

Morphology


  • BL tumor cells are monomorphic, medium-sized cells with round nuclei, multiple nucleoli, and basophilic cytoplasm.
  • Prominent cytoplasmic lipid vacuoles are usually evident on imprints or smears. There is an extremely high rate of proliferation, as well as a high rate of apoptotic cell death and a "starry-sky" pattern.
  • BL is strongly associated with a translocation among the long arm of chromosome 8, the site of the MYC oncogene (8q24), and one of three locations on Ig genes: t(8;14), t(2;8), or t(8;22).
  • All cases show overexpression of MYC protein.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought with 5-day history of high fever and fatigue. She has been crying more than usual and eating less. She also complained about pain in her arms and legs for the past 3 days. She appears ill. Her temperature is 103.1°F, pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 96/52 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic murmur is heard at the apex. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the left upper quadrant with no guarding or rebound. The spleen is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. There is no redness or swelling of the joints. Laboratory studies show: Hb 11.8 g/dL; Leukocyte count 16,300/mm3; Platelet count 220,000/mm3; ESR 50 mm/h; Serum Glucose 96 mg/dL; Creatinine 1.7 mg/dL; LFT normal; Urine- Protein 2+, RBC casts rare, RBC 10/hpf, WBC 1-2/hpf. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
• A previously healthy child has high fever, arthralgia, a new onset murmur, and splenomegaly. In combination with leukocytosis, elevated ESR and signs of glomerulonephritis are all suggestive of infective endocarditis.
  • In a patient with suspected IE, a minimum of 3 blood cultures from different venipuncture sites should be obtained as soon as possible and over a short period of time. The presence of bacterial type of IE (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus) obtained from 2 separate blood cultures is a major Duke criterion.
  • Because patients with IE usually have continuous bacteremia, blood cultures are positive in a high percentage of cases. Blood cultures should always be collected before initiating antibiotic therapy, so as to avoid potentially false negative results.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2453

questions.text: During Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI), when should cricoid pressure be released?
questions.solution:
• To perform Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI), the patient is always preoxygenated prior to induction. Patients with lung disease require 3-5 mins of preoxygenation.
  • An assistant may apply firm pressure over the cricoid cartilage prior to induction (Sellick Maneuver).
  • A propofol induction dose is given as a bolus. Other rapid-acting induction agents like etomidate, ketamine or methohexital may be substituted.
  • Succinycholine (1.5mg/kg) or rocuronium (0.9-1.2 mg/kg) is administered immediately following the induction dose, even if the patient has not yet lost consciousness
  • The patient is not ventilated with a bag and mask to avoid filling the stomach with gas and thereby increasing the risk of emesis. (A modification of the classic RSI allows gentle ventilation as long as cricoid pressure is maintained.)
  • Once muscle response to nerve stimulation has disappeared, the patient is rapidly intubated.
  • Cricoid pressure should be maintained until the endotracheal tube cuff is inflated and the tube position is confirmed.
  • If the intubation proves difficult, cricoid pressure is maintained, and the patient is gently ventilated with oxygen until another intubation attempt can be performed.
  • Tips to remember:

Sequence of 8 P's

  1. Prepare
  2. Preoxygenate
  3. Pretreatment + induction
  4. Paralysis
  5. Pressure (cricoid)
  6. Place tube and confirm position
  7. Pressure released
  8. Post-intubation care

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail’s Clinical Anaesthesiology, 7th ed., pg.468-469

questions.text: A 36yr old gentleman is presented to emergency room with history of RTA and has sustained head injury along with injury to left thigh. Relevant investigations reveal that he has SDH along with comminuted, intra-articular fracture of distal femur. His GCS is poor and the neuro-surgery team needs to operate him in emergency. What shall be the best plan of management from orthopaedic team?
questions.solution:
For deciding the plan of management there can not be one specific answer, but among the given options we can derive the correct answer by rule of exclusions.

Most displaced distal femur fractures are best treated with operative stabilization. Articular fractures require anatomic reconstruction of the joint surface and fixation with interfragmentary lag screws and plates. (hence, options 1 and 2 ruled out)

Skeletal traction is the preferred method of temporizing long bone, pelvic, and acetabular fractures until definitive operative treatment can be performed.

Schanz pins are used with external fixators as shown in image (hence option 3 is also ruled out)

Skeletal traction: The traction is applied directly on the bone by inserting a K-wire,Steinmann pin or Denham's pin through the bone.

Reference: Koval's Handbook of fractures' 5th edition, page no. 17, 387.

questions.text: Dependent Viscera sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
• The "dependent viscera sign" is a radiological finding seen on a chest X-ray or CT scan in cases of diaphragmatic injury.
  • It refers to the abnormal position of abdominal organs (viscera) that have herniated into the chest cavity due to a tear or rupture in the diaphragm. This sign is called "dependent" because the herniated organs appear to depend on or hang downward into the chest cavity.
  • Diaphragmatic injuries can occur due to trauma, such as blunt or penetrating trauma to the abdomen or chest. The herniation of abdominal organs into the chest cavity can lead to respiratory symptoms, gastrointestinal symptoms, or even life-threatening complications such as strangulation of the herniated organs.
  • The dependent viscera sign is one of the radiological findings that can suggest the presence of diaphragmatic injury. Viscera lie against the posterior ribs with obliteration of posterior costophrenic recess on a CT

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page no. 368-69

questions.text: Which of the following ligament replaces the ligamentum nuchae in thoracic region?
questions.solution:
Ligaments connecting adjacent thoracic vertebrae:

  • Apart from the intervertebral discs and the capsules around the joints between the articular processes, adjacent vertebrae are connected by several ligaments which are as follows.
  • The anterior longitudinal ligament passes from the anterior surface of the body of one vertebra to another. Its upper end reaches the basilar part of the occipital bone.
  • The posterior longitudinal ligament is present on the posterior surface of the vertebral bodies within the vertebral canal. Its upper end reaches the body of the axis vertebra (C2) beyond which it is continuous with the membrana tectoria.
  • The intertransverse ligaments connect adjacent transverse processes.
  • The interspinous ligaments connect adjacent spines.
  • The supraspinous ligaments connect the tips of the spines of vertebrae from the seventh cervical to the sacrum. In the cervical region, they are replaced by the ligamentum nuchae.
  • The ligamenta flava (singular = ligamentum flavum) connect the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. They are made up mainly of elastic tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following carbohydrate metabolisms is used for liver function assessment:
questions.solution:
• Galactose Tolerance test assesses the metabolic capacity of liver.
  • Galactose is almost entirely metabolized in the liver.
  • GALACTOSE IS NEEDED FOR THE SYNTHESIS OF LACTOSE, GLYCOLIPIDS, PROTEOGLYCANS, & GLYCOPROTEINS.
  • Galactose is derived from intestinal hydrolysis of the disaccharide lactose, the sugar found in milk. It is readily converted in the liver to glucose. Galactokinase catalyzes the phosphorylation of galactose, using ATP as phosphate donor.
  • Galactose 1-phosphate reacts with UDPGlc to form uridine diphosphate galactose (UDPGal) and glucose 1-phosphate, in a reaction catalyzed by galactose-1-phosphate uridyl
  • The conversion of UDPGal to UDPGlc is catalyzed by UDPGal 4-epimerase. The reaction involves oxidation, and then reduction, at carbon 4, with NAD+ as a coenzyme. The UDPGlc is then incorporated into glycogen.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition - Page 203

questions.text: Which amongst the following statement is most accurate regarding how would the presence of a non competitive antagonist affect the potency and efficacy of the receptor's endogenous ligand?
questions.solution:
Non competitive antagonists block signaling by binding to an allosteric site on the receptor. Since the drug doesn't affect the binding site, it does not change the endogenous ligand's ability to bind to the receptor, leading to unchanged potency.

However, even with increased concentrations, the ligand will not be able to out compete the drug, leading to decreased efficacy.

Competitive antagonists will lead to decreased ligand potency and unchanged efficacy.

Uncompetitive antagonists will lead to decreased ligand potency and decreased efficacy.

Non-competitive antagonists bind to an allosteric site on a receptor, leading to decreased ligand efficacy while leaving the potency unchanged.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 68-69

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable criteria for age estimation by Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
• Transparency of root: Occurs in root from below upwards in lower jaw and above downwards in upper jaw due to rarefaction of dentin tissue in which canals in the dentin are filled by minerals, so that they become translucent gradually and the dentine become. Most reliable criteria of all.
  • Root resorption: Root resorption starts first at the apex and extends upwards. Involves both cementum and dentin. Least reliable of all criteria.
  • Cementum apposition: The cementum increases in thickness around the root due to change in the tooth position. Continuously deposited throughout life and forms incremental lines.
  • Periodontosis: Regression of gums and periodontal tissues surrounding the teeth take place in advancing age exposing the neck and adjacent parts of roots. Poor oral hygiene increases periodontosis.
  • The other two criteria used in Gustaffson’s method are Attrition and Secondary dentine formation.

questions.text: A child born to Indian couples outside India, birth must be registered within
questions.solution:
When a child is born to Indian couples outside India, the birth must be registered with the Indian authorities upon their return to India. The registration process typically involves providing documentation and information about the birth to the concerned authorities within a specified timeframe.

d. 60 days of arrival to India: When a child is born to Indian couples outside India, the birth must be registered with the Indian authorities within 60 days of the parent's arrival in India after the child's birth abroad. This timeframe allows the parents a reasonable period to complete the necessary documentation and procedures upon their return to India.

Why the other options are not:

  1. 21 days: This option suggests that the birth must be registered within 21 days of the child's birth, regardless of whether the parents are in India or abroad. However, this is not applicable when the child is born outside India.
  2. 21 days of arrival to India: This option implies that the registration must occur within 21 days of the parent's arrival in India after the child's birth abroad. While this option considers the timeframe after returning to India, the correct timeframe for registration is typically longer.
  3. 60 days: This option suggests that the registration must occur within 60 days of the child's birth, regardless of whether the parents are in India or abroad. However, when a child is born to Indian couples outside India, the registration process usually begins upon their return to India rather than immediately after birth.

In summary, option D (60 days of arrival to India) is the correct answer because it accurately reflects the registration requirement for births of Indian couples outside India. The other options either specify incorrect timeframes or do not consider the circumstances of births that occur abroad.

questions.text: Which of the following statement regarding Kernicterus is false?
questions.solution:
• Kernicterus, or bilirubin encephalopathy, is a neurologic syndrome resulting from the deposition of unconjugated bilirubin in the basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei.
  • The greatest risk associated with hyperbilirubinemia is the development of kernicterus (bilirubin encephalopathy) at high indirect serum bilirubin levels.
  • The level of serum bilirubin associated with kernicterus is dependent in part on the cause of the jaundice. Kernicterus has developed when bilirubin levels exceed 30 mg/dL, although the range is wide (21-50 mg/dL).
  • Its onset is usually in the 1st week of life, but it may be delayed to the 2nd-3rd week.
  • Kernicterus develops at lower bilirubin levels in preterm infants and in the presence of asphyxia, intraventricular hemorrhage, hemolysis, or drugs that displace bilirubin from albumin. The exact serum bilirubin level that is harmful for VLBW infants is unclear. Kernicterus does occur in patients with breast milk jaundice but is very uncommon.
  • The surface of the brain is usually pale yellow. On cutting, certain regions are characteristically stained yellow by unconjugated bilirubin

questions.text: A 55 Year old male with progressive shortness of breath shows traction bronchiectasis, bibasal fibrosis with volume loss of lungs on HRCT, Barium swallow shows dilated patulous esophagus, most likely cause is?

Scleroderma

  • Scleroderma, or systemic sclerosis, is a connective tissue disorder characterized by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities. It can affect multiple organs, including the lungs and esophagus, leading to symptoms such as shortness of breath and esophageal dysfunction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old Female with no known medical problems is referred For Further evaluation of new onset anemia and thrombocytopenia. • Peripheral slide reveals the presence of spherocytes and reticulocytosis, which in the context of direct antiglobin test positivity and elevated LDH is consistent with the diagnosis of Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).

  • Felty syndrome (FS) (Choice B) is characterized by the presence of rheumatoid arthritis, neutropenia, and splenomegaly.
  • Absence of leukoerythroblastosis in peripheral blood argues against the presence of myelophthisic anemia. (Choice D)
  • Evans syndrome (ES) - It can present as a primary disorder or occur in context of another autoimmune condition. Management follows the algorithm for AIHA and ITP with the use of corticosteroids, splenectomy, rituximab, or other immunosuppressive agents. The course of ES tends to be more aggressive than that of either AIHA or ITP, and is characterized by a chronic course with frequent relapses.

questions.text: Acute CO poisoning produces which type of anoxia?
questions.solution:
• Anoxic anoxia: Oxygen cannot reach the blood, because of lack of oxygen in the lungs. This occurs from breathing in a contaminated atmosphere e.g. exposure to fumes in wells and tanks, or from exposure to sewer gas etc OR from mechanical interference with the passage. g. smothering, choking, hanging, drowning etc
  • Anaemic anoxia: The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is reduced. It is seen in acute massive haemorrhage, CO poisoning, chlorate poisoning etc.
  • Stagnant anoxia: Impaired circulation results in reduction of oxygen delivery to the tissues. It is seen in heart failure, embolism and shock.
  • Histotoxic anoxia: The enzymatic process through which the oxygen in the blood is used by the tissues is blocked. It is seen in acute cyanide poisoning.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Dr.K S Narayan Reddy, 35th Edition, Chapter: 6, Page no. 101.

questions.text: Which of the following is the national level system that provides annual national as well as state level reliable estimates of fertility and mortality?
questions.solution:
• Sample Registration System (SRS) (Option D):
    • The Sample Registration System (SRS) is a national-level system in India that provides annual reliable estimates of fertility (birth rates) and mortality (death rates) at both national and state levels.
    • SRS operates under the Office of the Registrar General & Census Commissioner, India, and is designed to provide continuous demographic data through a sample survey methodology.
    • It covers a representative sample of households across the country and collects data on births, deaths, and other vital events to estimate fertility and mortality rates, which are crucial for demographic analysis and policy planning.

Why the other options are not correct:

  • Civil Registration System (Option A):
    • The Civil Registration System (CRS) is a method of recording vital events such as births, deaths, marriages, and divorces through a legal system administered by local governments.
    • While the CRS is essential for maintaining accurate demographic records, it typically does not provide annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality rates in India.
  • Census (Option B):
    • The census is a comprehensive enumeration of the population conducted at regular intervals, usually every ten years.
    • While the census provides valuable demographic data, including information on population size and distribution, it is not specifically designed to provide annual estimates of fertility and mortality rates.
  • Ad-hoc Survey (Option C):
    • Ad-hoc surveys refer to one-time or occasional surveys conducted for specific research or data collection purposes.
    • While ad-hoc surveys may provide useful information on various topics, they are not typically used to generate annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality on a continuous basis.

In summary, the Sample Registration System (SRS) is the correct answer as it is specifically designed to provide annual national and state-level estimates of fertility and mortality in India. Unlike the other options, SRS operates through a systematic sample survey methodology, allowing for the continuous collection and analysis of demographic data essential for policy planning and decision-making.

questions.text: A previously healthy 15-month-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation for a 3-day history of persistent vomiting and diarrhea. Which of the following is the best acute indicator of a child's hydration status?
questions.solution:
• An acute change in weight is the best determinant of a person's current hydration status; indeed, our estimates of dehydration are reported in percentages of weight loss.
  • However, previous weights are not often available and are not necessary for decision making in resuscitation scenarios such as in this vignette.
  • If a child just so happens to have had a recent visit for medical care and if the weight measurements were obtained on the same scale, the level of the child's dehydration can be determined accurately.
  • Urine output is a good indicator of hydration status and is used in virtually all inpatient settings although it is not as reliable a measurement as an acute change in weight and at times can be No role of cardiac output measurement
  • Clinical signs of dehydration may be the only available indicators of a child's hydration status but can be subjective, subtle, or both.

Antisnake venom (ASV) serum polyvalent

questions.text: Yield of a test depends upon
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d. All of the above.

  1. Sensitivity: Sensitivity is the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who have the disease (true positives) among all individuals who actually have the disease. A higher sensitivity means the test is better at detecting the disease when it is present. Sensitivity directly affects the number of true positive results obtained from the test. If a test has high sensitivity, it will capture more cases of the disease, contributing to a higher yield.
  2. Specificity: Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the disease (true negatives) among all individuals who actually do not have the disease. A higher specificity means the test is better at correctly identifying individuals without the disease. Specificity affects the number of true negative results obtained from the test. If a test has high specificity, it will correctly exclude individuals without the disease, contributing to a higher yield by reducing false positive results.
  3. Prevalence: Prevalence refers to the proportion of individuals in a population who have the disease at a specific point in time. The prevalence of a disease in the population being tested directly influences the number of true positive and true negative results obtained from the test. In populations with higher disease prevalence, there are more cases of the disease present, leading to more true positive results and potentially fewer false negative results, which can contribute to a higher yield. Conversely, in populations with lower disease prevalence, there are fewer cases of the disease present, which may result in fewer true positive results and potentially more false negative results, affecting the overall yield of the test.
  4. Combined Influence: Sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence all play crucial roles in determining the yield of a test. A test with high sensitivity and specificity may yield more accurate results, especially in populations with varying disease prevalence. However, the yield of a test is not solely dependent on any single factor; rather, it is influenced by the interplay of sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence in the population being tested.

Therefore, the correct answer is d. All of the above, as sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence collectively influence the yield of a test. Each of these factors contributes to the overall performance and effectiveness of the test in identifying individuals with the disease and obtaining accurate results.

questions.text: Most Radioresistant phase of cell cycle is?
questions.solution:
• Most Radiosensitive phase of cell cycle is the G2-M interphase or M phase.
  • Most Radioresistant phase of cell cycle is the late S phase.
    • During the S phase of the cell cycle, which stands for synthesis, the cell's DNA is replicated. This means that the genetic material is duplicated to prepare for cell division. This phase is crucial for cell division because each new cell needs a complete set of DNA.
    • Cells in the S phase are more radioresistant because the process of DNA replication provides additional mechanisms for repairing radiation-induced damage to DNA. The cell has enzymes and other proteins that can recognize and repair damaged DNA, helping the cell survive radiation exposure.
    • In contrast, cells in the G1 (first gap) and G2 (second gap) phases are less radioresistant. While G1 is a preparatory phase for DNA replication and cell division, it doesn't have the same level of DNA repair mechanisms as the S phase. G2 is a phase of further preparation for cell division, and although it has some DNA repair mechanisms, they are not as active as in the S phase.
    • The M phase (mitosis), where the cell actually divides into two daughter cells, is also relatively sensitive to radiation because the DNA is condensed and more vulnerable to damage.

Reference: Textbook of Radiology and Imaging by Sutton, Edition 8, Vol I, Page no. 14-16

questions.text: A 35-year-old man undergoes surgery for a hernia repair. After the surgery, he complains of diffuse muscle aches, which the anesthesiologist states is likely caused by the skeletal muscle relaxant. He has a temperature of 37.8°C (100°F). Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding his muscle aches?
questions.solution:
Myalgia (muscle aches) is a common adverse reaction of depolarizing agents such as succinylcholine; these agents also may induce hyperkalemia and malignant hyperthermia.

Adverse reactions of SMRs:

  1. Respiratory paralysis and prolonged apnoea is the most important complication of neuromuscular blockers.
  2. Flushing (due to histamine release) is common with d-TC, can occur with atracurium and mivacurium, rare with others.
  3. Fall in BP and cardiovascular collapse can occur, especially in hypovolemic patients.
  4. Cardiac arrhythmias and even arrest have occurred, especially with SCh, particularly in digitalized patients, because SCh releases K+ from muscles.
  5. Precipitation of asthma by histamine releasing neuromuscular blockers.
  6. Postoperative muscle soreness and myalgia may be complained after SCh, particularly when larger dose is used.
  7. Malignant hyperthermia can be triggered by SCh in patients anaesthetized with fluorinated anaesthetics.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 381

questions.text:

iii) Affinity to hemoglobin is 200-300 times greater than oxygen
iv) Produces death due to histotoxic anoxia
v) Acts as chemical asphyxiant
questions.solution:

questions.text: A drug company is developing a new pregnancy test kit for use on an OP basis. The company used pregnancy test on 100 women who are known to be pregnant. Out of 100 women 99 showed positive test. Upon using the same test on 100 non pregnant women, 90 showed negative results. What is the specificity of the test?
questions.solution:
Specificity measures the ability of a test to correctly identify individuals who do not have the condition (true negatives) among those who truly do not have the condition.

Calculating the specificity of the test:

Specificity is defined as the proportion of true negative results among all individuals who do not have the condition (in this case, pregnancy). It can be calculated using the formula:

Specificity = True Negatives / {True Negatives + False Positives}

Given that the test was performed on 100 non-pregnant women and 90 of them showed negative results, these 90 negative results are the true negatives. However, we also need to account for the possibility of false positives.

In the scenario provided, the test was performed on 100 non-pregnant women, and 90 of them showed negative results. Therefore, the remaining 10 women must have shown positive results. However, these 10 positive results are false positives because the women are not actually pregnant.

Now, let's plug these values into the specificity formula:

Specificity = 90/{90 + 10}

Specificity = 90/100 =0.90

Multiplying by 100 to express it as a percentage, we get:

Specificity} = 90%

Therefore, the specificity of the test is 90%. This means that among non-pregnant women, the test correctly identifies 90% of them as negative, indicating a high level of accuracy in ruling out pregnancy. Hence, the correct answer is option a. 90%.

questions.text: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a known long-term complication of which of the following infections?

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE)

  • Clinical presentation: characterized by four clinical stages

questions.text: A 57-year-old female noticed swelling of her eyelids and she has experienced nausea and vomiting several times in the past two days. Her vital signs are a temperature of 98.6°F, blood pressure of 107/72 mm Hg, and pulse of 91 bpm. Laboratory testing reveals an albumin of 2.2 gm/dL and total cholesterol of 243 mg/dL. A urinalysis is positive for protein, negative for red blood cells, and white blood cells. She is admitted to the hospital. Overnight testing reveals 4.1 g/24 hrs of protein in the urine. Immunofluorescence staining reveals granular IgG positivity, and electron microscopy reveals subepithelial immune complexes. Of the following, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Based on the signs and symptoms (edema), and laboratory testing identifying proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidaemia, the diagnosis is nephrotic syndrome.
  • NEPHROTIC SYNDROME
    1. Minimal change disease
    2. Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)
    3. Membranous glomerulonephropathy
  • FSGS can have positive immunofluorescence due to entrapped IgM and C3 but has no immune complex deposits (choice c).
  • Membranous glomerulonephropathy has granular IgG positivity and subepithelial immune complex deposits (choice b).
  • Post- infectious glomerulonephritis can have granular IgG positivity and subepithelial immune complexes, but also intramembranous and subendothelial immune complex deposits, and causes nephritic syndrome (choice A).
  • Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis causes nephritic syndrome and has subendothelial immune complex deposits (choice d).

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman recently diagnosed with mild rheumatoid arthritis started a therapy with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), but 2 months later, the physician decided to add a disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drug (DMARD) to the therapeutic regimen. Which of the following is most likely the main advantage of DMARDs over NSAIDs in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
NSAIDs were once considered the first-line treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, but today they are used only as needed to control pain because it has been shown that they have little effect on bone and cartilage destruction.

On the contrary, DMARDs can arrest, or at least slow down, the progression of the disease. They are slow-acting drugs, and their effect may take 6 weeks to 6 months to become evident. Therefore, DMARD treatment should not be delayed beyond 3 months of arthritis diagnosis for the majority of patients.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, page no. 228

questions.text: NPU value for egg is
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option B: 96.

b. 96: This value is accurate for the NPU of eggs. Eggs are often regarded as a reference protein due to their high-quality protein content and digestibility. The NPU of eggs is typically around 96, indicating that a significant proportion of the protein consumed from eggs is retained and utilized by the body for various physiological functions.

Why the other option is not correct:

a. 140: This value is not accurate for the Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of eggs. NPU values typically range from 60 to 96, depending on the protein source and the method of calculation. An NPU of 140 would be unusually high and not reflective of the actual protein quality of eggs.

c. 81: This value is not accurate for the NPU of eggs either. While NPU values can vary depending on factors such as protein source and processing, an NPU of 81 would be lower than typical values reported for eggs.

d. 52: This value is significantly lower than the typical NPU value for eggs. Eggs are considered one of the highest quality protein sources, with NPU values typically ranging from 60 to 96. A value of 52 would suggest poor protein quality, which is not consistent with the nutritional profile of eggs.

In summary, option B (96) is the correct answer for the NPU value of eggs. Options A, C, and D provide values that are either too high or too low and do not accurately reflect the protein quality of eggs. Therefore, option B is the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not found in child with Kwashiorkor?
questions.solution:
• General appearance: Child may have a fat sugar baby appearance.
  • Edema: It ranges from mild to gross and may represent up to 5-20% of the body weight.
  • Muscle wasting: It is always prese The child is often weak, hypotonic and unable to stand or walk.
  • Skin changes: The skin lesions consist of increased pigmentation, desquamation and dyspigmentation. Pigmentation may be confluent resembling flaky paint or in individual enamel spots. The distribution is typically on buttocks, perineum and upper thigh.
  • Petechiae may be seen over abdomen. Outer layers of skin may peel off and ulceration may occur. The lesions may sometimes resemble burns.
  • Mucous membrane lesions: Smooth tongue, cheilosis and angular stomatitis are Herpes simplex stomatitis may also be seen.
  • Hair: Changes include dyspigmentation, loss of characteristic curls and sparseness over temple and occipital regions. Hair loose their luster and are easily pluckable. A flag sign which is the alternate bands of hypopigmented and normally pigmented hair pattern is seen when the growth of child occurs in spurts.
  • Mental changes: Includes unhappiness, apathy, or irritability with sad, intermittent cry. They show no signs of hunger and it is difficult to feed them.
  • Neurological changes: Changes such as tremors are seen during recovery.
  • Gastrointestinal system: Anorexia, sometimes with vomiting, is the rule. Abdominal distension is characteristic. Stools may be watery or semisolid, bulky with a low pH and may contain unabsorbed sugars. Fat deposition in liver.
  • Anemia: Nutritional anemia is almost always associated.
  • Cardiovascular system: The findings include cold, pale extremities due to circulatory insufficiency and are associated with prolonged circulation time, bradycardia, diminished cardiac output and hypotension.
  • Renal function: Glomerular filtration and renal plasma flow are There is aminoaciduria and inefficient excretion of acid load.

Reference: Ghai's Essential pediatrics, 9th ed., pg. 96

questions.text: An adolescent boy aged 14yrs presents with complain of painful limp in left lower limb since 2 weeks. He faintly remembers an episode of trivial trauma while playing in school around 10 days back. Xray of left hip is as follows. Diagnose the condition:
questions.solution:
Weakness in femoral capital epiphysis and rapid growth during adolescence leads to displacement of femoral neck and shaft away from the epiphysis called SCFE. Though the epiphysis itself maintains its relation with the acetabulum. The name is misnomer as it is the femoral neck and shaft that displaces (slips) and not the epiphysis.

Usually the limp in slipped capital femoral epiphysis is painless initially and often an episode of minor injury is present which may/may not be the cause of the problem. As the complains in this case are from 2 weeks the history of trivial trauma is of little importance.

SCFE is a condition which is commonly seen in 10-15yrs, boys > girls, left > right.

Reference: Tachdjian's Pediatric Orthopaedics 5th edition page no. 630

questions.text: In weightlifting exercise which of the following energy system is commonly useful
questions.solution:
Weightlifting is a short duration exercise which uses immediately available ATPs.

  • Aerobic system can generate large no. of ATPs but at very slow rate is useful for long duration exercise like marathon.
  • Glycogen lactic acid system generates 2.5 moles of ATP in case of insufficient oxygen. anaerobic glycolysis mechanism can be used as a rapid source of energy. However,
  • it is only about one-half as rapid as the phosphagen system.
  • A special characteristic of energy transfer from phosphocreatine to ATP occurs within a small fraction of a second. Therefore, all the energy stored in muscle phosphocreatine is almost instantaneously available for immediate use in muscle contraction, just as is the energy stored in ATP.

questions.text: Most hazardous pesticide colour coding is
questions.solution:
A. Red: In many countries, including India, red is commonly used as the colour coding for the most hazardous pesticides. These pesticides are classified as highly toxic and pose significant risks to human health and the environment. The red colour serves as a warning to handlers and users to exercise extreme caution when dealing with these substances. They often require special handling, storage, and disposal procedures to minimize exposure and prevent adverse effects.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

B. Green: Green colour coding is typically used for moderately hazardous pesticides. These pesticides have a lower toxicity compared to those labelled with red, but they still pose risks if not handled properly. While green-coded pesticides may require less stringent precautions than red-coded ones, they still necessitate careful handling and storage to prevent harm to human health and the environment.

C. Yellow: Yellow colour coding is commonly used for less hazardous pesticides, which are classified as slightly toxic. These pesticides pose fewer risks compared to red and green-coded pesticides but still require proper handling and precautions to ensure safety. Yellow-coded pesticides may have lower toxicity levels and fewer adverse effects on human health and the environment, but they still need to be used responsibly.

D. Black: Black is not typically used as a colour coding for pesticides based on toxicity levels. Instead, black may be used for other purposes, such as labelling containers for non-pesticidal substances or equipment. Pesticides labelled with black are not associated with specific toxicity levels or hazard classifications.

In summary, the most hazardous pesticides are often color-coded red to signify their high toxicity and associated risks. Therefore, option A (Red) is the correct choice for the most hazardous pesticide colour coding.

questions.text: A 33-week, 1200 g boy is born to a teenage mother who had poor prenatal care. The baby's head circumference, height, and weight are below average for his age, indicating poor intrauterine growth, likely due to exposure to drugs during pregnancy. Which of the following maternal drugs can be a cause of IUGR in this child?
questions.solution:
• Phenytoin has been associated with IUGR as well as other congenital anomalies.
  • IUGR is associated with medical conditions that interfere with the circulation and efficiency of the placenta, with the development or growth of the fetus, or with the general health and nutrition of the mother.
  • IUGR is often classified as reduced growth that is symmetric (head circumference, length, and weight equally affected) or asymmetric (with relative sparing of head growth).
  • Symmetric IUGR often has an earlier onset and is associated with diseases that seriously affect fetal cell number, such as conditions with chromosomal, genetic, malformation, teratogenic, infectious, or severe maternal hypertensive etiologies.
  • Asymmetric IUGR is often of late onset and is associated with poor maternal nutrition or with late onset or exacerbation of maternal vascular disease (preeclampsia, chronic hypertension).
  • Other drugs such as narcotics, alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine, and antimetabolites are commonly a cause of IUGR.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 3106

questions.text: Identify the Degree of Heart block
questions.solution:
• ECG with a prolonged P-R interval; first-degree block is defined as a delay of conduction from the atria to the ventricles but not actual blockage of conduction. The P-R interval seldom increases above 0.35 to 0.45 second because, by that time, conduction through the A-V bundle is depressed so much that conduction stops entirely.
  • Mobitz Type I block is characterized by progressive prolongation of the P-R interval until a ventricular beat is dropped and is then followed by resetting of the P-R interval and repeating of the abnormal cycle. A type I block is almost always caused by abnormality of the A-V node. In most cases, this type of block is benign.
  • Mobitz type II block, there is usually a fixed number of non conducted P waves for every QRS complex. For example, a 2:1 block implies that there are two P waves for every QRS complex.
  • 3rd degree or complete block of the impulse from the atria into the ventricles occurs. In this case, the ventricles spontaneously establish their own signal, usually originating in the A-V node or A-V bundle distal to the block. Therefore, the P waves become dissociated from the QRS-T complexes

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Ed Ch 13 Pg. 159

questions.solution:
Metolazone In common with loop diuretics, it is able to evoke a clinically useful response even in severe renal failure (g.f.r. ~15 ml/min), and has marked additive action when combined with furosemide.

An additional proximal tubular action has been demonstrated; PO4 reabsorption that occurs in PT, is inhibited. It is excreted unchanged in urine. Metolazone has been used mainly for edema.

questions.text: Community health centre covering a population of
questions.solution:
The correct answer is C. 80,000 to 1,20,000.

Community Health Centres (CHCs) are the second tier of the healthcare infrastructure in India, catering to a larger population than Primary Health Centres (PHCs) and providing comprehensive healthcare services. The population coverage of a CHC is crucial in determining its capacity and resources to serve the community effectively.

Why the other options are not correct:

A. 40,000 to 60,000:This population range is typically covered by a Primary Health Centre (PHC), not a Community Health Centre (CHC). CHCs are designed to serve larger populations.

B. 60,000 to 80,000: While this population range is closer to the typical coverage of a CHC, it is still on the lower end. CHCs are generally established to serve larger populations than this range.

D. None: This option is incorrect because CHCs do cover a specific population range. They are an essential part of the healthcare infrastructure in India, providing secondary healthcare services to communities within a defined geographical area.

Therefore, option C, covering a population of 80,000 to 1,20,000, is the most appropriate population range for a Community Health Centre (CHC). This range ensures that the CHC has adequate resources and facilities to provide comprehensive healthcare services to a substantial number of people within its catchment area.

questions.text: Name the topical agent used in treatment for burn wound reduces cell mediated immunosuppression
questions.solution:
• Silver sulphadiazine cream (1%). This gives broad spectrum prophylaxis against bacterial colonisation and is particularly effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and also methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.
  • Silver nitrate solution (0.5%). Again, this is highly effective as a prophylaxis against Pseudomonas colonisation, but it is not as active as silver sulphadiazine cream against some of the gram-negative aerobes. The other disadvantage of this solution is that it needs to be changed or the wounds resoaked every 2-4 hours. It also produces black staining of all the furniture surrounding the patient.
  • Mafenide acetate cream. This is popular, especially in the United States, but is painful to apply. It is usually used as a 5% topical solution, but has been associated with metabolic acidosis.
  • Silver sulphadiazine and cerium nitrate. This is also a very useful burn dressing, especially for full-thickness burns. It induces a sterile eschar on the burned skin and has been shown in certain instances, especially in elderly patients, to reduce some of the cell-mediated immunosuppression that occurs in burns. Cerium nitrate forms a sterile eschar and is especially useful in treating burns when a conservative treatment option has been chosen. Cerium nitrate has also been shown to boost cell-mediated immunity in these patients.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 46, Edition: 28th, Pg: 674

choices.text: The amount of air that normally moves into (or out of) the lung with each respiration.
The amount of air that enters the lung but does not participate in gas exchange.
The amount of air expired after maximal expiratory effort.
The amount of air expired forcefully after maximal inspiratory effort

questions.text: The forced vital capacity is
questions.solution:
• The amount of air that normally moves into or out of lungs with each respiration is called tidal volume which is 500 ml
  • The amount of air that enters the lung but does not participate in gas exchange is called dead space air that is 150 ml per breath.
  • The amount of air expired after maximal expiratory effort is residual volume that is approx. 1200 ml.
  • The amount of air expired forcefully after maximal inspiratory effort is forced vital capacity which is around 4800 ml noted in relation to time. It has normally 3 components. (FEV1, FEV2, FEV3)

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with aggressive behaviour and poor concentration is brought with presenting complaints of joint pain and reduced urinary output. Mother gives a history of self-mutilating his finger. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be deficient in this child:
questions.solution:
• Phosphoryl transfer from PRPP is catalysed by adenosine and hypoxanthine-phosphoribosyl transferases, converting adenine, hypoxanthine, and guanine to their mononucleotides.
  • HGPRTase is the enzyme which converts hypoxanthine to IMP and Guanine to GMP.
  • The Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, an overproduction hyperuricemia characterized by frequent episodes of uric acid lithiasis and a bizarre syndrome of self-mutilation, reflects a defect in hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase, an enzyme of purine salvage .
  • The accompanying rise in intracellular PRPP results in purine overproduction.
  • Mutations that decrease or abolish hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase activity include deletions, frameshift mutations, base substitutions, and aberrant mRNA splicing.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition - Page 350,354

questions.text: Which of the following is false for the following gallbladder lesion?
questions.solution:
CHOLESTEROSIS (or CHOLESTEROLOSIS) of the gallbladder

  • It is accumulation of lipid within macrophages in the lamina propria.
  • Prevalence ranging between 9% and 26%.
  • Cholesterolosis is often associated with cholesterol gallstones. (Choice A)
  • The gross appearance is characteristic: linear yellow streaks are seen in the prominences of the mucosal ridges, surrounded by congested mucosa ("strawberry gallbladder"; Fig.) (Choice B)
  • Sometimes one or more of the deposits grow larger and protrude into the lumen, in which case they are referred to as cholesterolpolyps.
  • Microscopically, collections of lipid-filled foamy cells are present in the tips of the villi.
  • Inflammatory changes are usually insignificant, unless the cholesterosis is accompanied by stones in the cystic duct. (Choice C)

XANTHOGRANULOMATOUS CHOLECYSTITIS:

  • The gallbladder has a massively thickened wall and is shrunken, nodular, and chronically inflamed with foci of necrosis and hemorrhage. (Choice D)

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to medicine OPD with complains of the abrupt onset of her chest pounding. She is diagnosed with paroxysmal atrial tachycardia. Which of the following is the most effective agent for converting paroxysmal atrial tachycardia to normal sinus rhythm?
questions.solution:
Adenosine

Adenosine is an ultrashort acting endogenous purine signal molecule. Administered by rapid i.v. injection it terminates within 30 sec. more than 90% episodes of PSVT involving the A-V node.

It activates ACh sensitive K+ channels to accentuate inward rectifier K+ current and causes membrane hyperpolarization through interaction with A1 type of adenosine GPCRs on SA node fibers (pacemaker depression → bradycardia), on A-V node fibres (prolongation of ERP → slowing of conduction) and in atrium (shortening of AP, reduced excitability).

Adenosine indirectly reduces Ca2+ current in A-V node.

Depression of the re-entrant circuit through A-V node is responsible for termination of majority of PSVTs.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 581

questions.text: Optimum unit of preventive, promotive and curative services in health care is known as
questions.solution:
In healthcare, the term "comprehensiveness" refers to the provision of a wide range of preventive, promotive, and curative services to address the diverse health needs of individuals and communities. It involves offering a holistic approach to healthcare that encompasses various aspects of health promotion, disease prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation.

D. Comprehensiveness: Comprehensiveness encompasses the holistic provision of preventive, promotive, and curative services aimed at addressing the overall health needs of individuals and communities. It emphasizes the importance of offering a broad spectrum of interventions, including health education, immunization, screening, diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up care, to achieve optimal health outcomes.

Why the other options are not correct:

A. Appropriateness: While appropriateness is important in healthcare delivery, it specifically refers to the suitability or relevance of a particular intervention or service for a given health condition or situation. It does not encompass the broad scope of services provided by a healthcare unit.

B. Availability: Availability refers to the accessibility and presence of healthcare services or resources when needed by individuals or communities. While availability is essential for effective healthcare delivery, it does not necessarily address the comprehensiveness of services provided.

C. Adequacy: Adequacy pertains to the sufficiency or satisfactory level of healthcare resources, including facilities, staff, and equipment, to meet the needs of the population served. While adequacy is an important aspect of healthcare quality, it does not fully capture the range and diversity of services offered by a healthcare unit.

Therefore, option D, comprehensiveness, is the most appropriate term to describe the optimal unit of preventive, promotive, and curative services in healthcare. It reflects the importance of offering a comprehensive range of services to meet the diverse health needs of the population

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl comes with fever and rashes for 6 days. On examination she has diffuse macular rashes, conjunctival congestion, fissured lips enlarged cervical lymph nodes, strawberry tongue and periungual desquamation. Which of the following is not a proven treatment option for the child?
questions.solution:
CLASSIC CLINICAL CRITERIA

  • Fever persisting at least 5 days
  • Presence of at least 4 principal features:
    • Changes in extremities:
      • Acute: Erythema of palms, soles; edema of hands, feet
      • Subacute: Periungual peeling of fingers, toes in weeks 2 and 3
    • Polymorphous exanthem
    • Bilateral bulbar conjunctival injection without exudate
    • Changes in lips and oral cavity: erythema, lip cracking, strawberry tongue, diffuse injection of oral and pharyngeal mucosa
    • Cervical lymphadenopathy (>1.5 cm diameter), usually unilateral
  • Exclusion of other diseases with similar findings
  • Patients with acute KD should be treated with 2 g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day divided q6h) within 10 days of disease onset and ideally as soon as possible after diagnosis.
  • Most experts add warfarin or low-molecular-weight heparin for those patients at particularly high risk of thrombosis.
  • There is no role of plasmapheresis in such patients
  • Corticosteroids in varying doses and via different routes have also been used as secondary or "rescue" therapy when fever persists after the first IVIG. However, the lack of clear data regarding the most effective way to administer corticosteroids as rescue therapy has led to significant practice variation across centers.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1310

questions.text: All of the following are true for typhoid fever, except:
questions.solution:
Typhoid fever (enteric fever)

  • The disease is caused by Salmonella enterica and its two subtypes,
    • Typhi
    • paratyphi
  • In endemic countries - S. Typhi
  • Among travelers - S. Paratyphi
  • Humans are the sole reservoir for S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi;
  • Transmission - from person to person or via food or contaminated water
  • Clinical features : Rose spots, small erythematous maculopapular lesions, develop on the chest and abdomen. Symptoms abate after several weeks but relapse can occur.
  • Acute infection results in anorexia, abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, vomiting, and bloody diarrhea followed by a short asymptomatic phase that gives way to bacteremia and fever with flu-like symptoms
  • Salmonella infection causes Peyer patches in the terminal ileum (choice B) to enlarge into sharply delineated, plateau-like elevations up to 8 cm in diameter
  • Ulcers - Mucosal damage creates oval ulcers, oriented along the axis of the ileum, that may perforate. (Choice C)
  • In disseminated S. typhi infection, the spleen is enlarged and soft, with uniformly pale red pulp, obliterated follicular markings, and prominent phagocyte hyperplasia.
  • The liver is punctuated by small, randomly scattered foci of parenchymal necrosis in which hepatocytes are replaced by macrophage aggregates, called typhoid nodules, which may also be found in the bone marrow and lymph nodes (choice D)

questions.text: Physical examination of a 6-month-old child who does not walk reveals the findings shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The unequal leg length and asymmetry of the inguinal (anterior) and thigh (posterior) skin creases are indicative of severe developmental dysplasia of the hip.
  • DDH in the neonate is asymptomatic and must be screened for by specific maneuvers.
    • The Barlow provocative maneuver assesses the potential for dislocation of a non-displaced hip. The examiner adducts the flexed hip and gently pushes the thigh posteriorly in an effort to dislocate the femoral head. In a positive test, the hip is felt to slide out of the acetabulum. As the examiner relaxes the proximal push, the hip can be felt to slip back into the acetabulum.
    • The Ortolani test is the reverse of Barlow test: The examiner attempts to reduce a dislocated hip. The examiner grasps the child's thigh between the thumb and index finger and, with the 4th and 5th fingers, lifts the greater trochanter while simultaneously abducting the hip. When the test is positive, the femoral head will slip into the socket with a delicate clunk that is palpable but usually not audible. It should be a gentle, nonforced maneuver.
    • A hip click is the high-pitched sensation (or sound) felt at the very end of abduction during testing for DDH with Barlow and Ortolani maneuvers. Classically, a hip click is differentiated from a hip clunk, which is felt as the hip goes in and out of joint.
  • Ultrasonography is the diagnostic modality of choice for DDH before the appearance of the femoral head ossific nucleus (4-6 months).
  • Treatment:
    • Birth to 6 months- treated with a Pavlik harness as soon as the diagnosis is made.
    • 6 Months to 2 years- Closed reductions are performed
    • 2-6 years- Require an open reduction.
  • Equinovarus deformity do not affect leg length or inguinal skin creases.
  • Arthrogryposis is associated with severe joint contractures.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 3766

  • CUSHING ULCERS refer to gastric, duodenal, and esophageal ulcers arising in those with intracranial disease. They have an elevated risk of perforation. (Choice C)
  • Aplastic anemia can result from an idiosyncratic reaction in patients taking the antibiotic chloramphenicol.(Choice D)
  • Reye syndrome is associated with extensive microvesicular fatty change of the liver in children taking aspirin during an acute viral illness. (Choice A)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 17, Pg no 767.

choices.text: Shift of blood from pulmonary to systemic circuit

questions.text: A 71 year old male patient brought to emergency room with acute dyspnoea. He also had history of recent myocardial infarction with acute left ventricular failure. His physician had prescribed intravenous morphine along with other drugs. Which of the following mechanism is least useful by which Morphine affords symptomatic relief of dyspnoea in acute left ventricular failure?
questions.solution:
Acute left ventricular failure/acute pulmonary edema

Morphine injected i.v. affords dramatic relief by-

(a) Reducing preload on heart due to vasodilatation and peripheral pooling of blood.

(b) Tending to shift blood from pulmonary to systemic circuit; relieves pulmonary congestion and edema.

(c) Allaying air hunger and dyspnoea by depressing respiratory centre.

(d) Cutting down sympathetic stimulation by calming the patient, thereby reduces cardiac work.

Morphine is also indicated to relieve pulmonary edema due to infarction of lung, but not due to irritant gases.

It is contraindicated in bronchial asthma.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi 8th edition, Page no. 506-507

questions.text: A 16 year old boy was admitted with complaints of sudden onset palpitations. ECG was performed that showed a coved pattern of ST segment elevation in leads V2 and V3. He has a past history of unexplained syncope. What is the most likely diagnosis ?

BRUGADA SYNDROME

questions.text: The inpatient pediatric team is discussing the causes of failure to thrive (FTT) as they evaluate a 9-month-old infant with weight and length below the 5th percentile. Which of the following should be included in the differential diagnosis of infant who is not thriving?
questions.solution:
• Failure to thrive typically refers to children under the age of 5 whose growth parameters fall below the lower limits of the normal range.
  • There are many causes of failure to thrive, including psychosocial, medical (organic), nutritional, and developmental.
  • Cystic fibrosis is an important cause of failure to thrive and should be excluded in such cases.
  • Children with small atrial septal defects, acute bacterial meningitis, or recurrent otitis media generally do not fail to thrive unless they have another underlying condition.

Reference: Nelson pediatric symptom-based diagnosis, pg. 144

questions.text: A 45 year old patient from Bihar presents with hypopigmented lesions on trunk, without lesional sensory loss. There is a history of prolonged fever in childhood. What will be the finding in lesional slit skin smear ?
questions.solution:
• Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL), as the name suggests, is a sequel of kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis (VL)
  • Cutaneous lesions ranging from hypopigmented macules to erythematous papules and from nodules to plaques; the lesions may be numerous and persist for decades.
  • The rash usually starts around the mouth from where it spreads to other parts of the body depending on severity.
  • It is largely restricted to areas where Leishmania donovani is the causative parasite. The interval at which PKDL follows VL is 2-3 years in India.
  • Diagnosis is mainly clinical, but parasites can be seen by microscopy in smears with limited sensitivity.
  • PKDL and lepromatous leprosy are known clinical simulants with similar morphological picture.
  • No nerve thickening/sensorimotor loss differentiate PKDL from LL leprosy
  • However, the characteristic morphology of infecting organisms is different in a stained slit-skin smear preparation or tissue aspirate.
  • SSS in PKDL - LD bodies, intracellular amastigate forms of the parasite

questions.text: All of the following are the common aetiologies of sudden cardiac death, except:
questions.solution:
• The mechanism of SCD is most often a lethal arrhythmia (e.g., asystole or ventricular fibrillation).
  • CAD is the leading cause of SCD, responsible for the Majority of cases; unfortunately, SCD can be the first manifestation of IHD.
  • With younger victims, nonatherosclerotic causes are more common etiologies for SCD:
    • Cardiac conduction abnormalities, hereditary or acquired
    • Dilated or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
    • Congenital coronary arterial abnormalities
    • Myocarditis
    • Mitral valve prolapse
    • Pulmonary hypertension

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, Pg no 555.

questions.text: Disc diffusion method is also known as-
questions.solution:
• Disc diffusion test is a culture-based microbiology assay used in diagnostic and drug discovery laboratories.
  • It is also known as Kiby Bauer Technique.

In diagnostic labs they are used to determine the susceptibility of bacteria isolated from a patient's infection to clinically approved antibiotics.

In this standardized inoculum is swabbed on Muller Hilton agar and different discs are put on it.

After overnight incubation, we can see zone of inhibition around disc and as per CLSI guidelines we can give either resistant, sensitive or intermediate.

questions.text: Which of the following Melatonin agonist approved for use in non-24-hour sleep-wake disorder in totally blind patients with circadian rhythm disorder?
questions.solution:
Tasimelteon is a selective agonist for MT1 and MT2 receptors. Approved for the treatment of non-24-h sleep-wake syndrome in totally blind patients experiencing circadian rhythm disorder by FDA.

The FDA expanded the use of tasimelteon for the treatment of night time sleep disturbances in adults and children with Smith-Magenis syndrome, a rare neuro-developmental disorder involving reversed circadian rhythm that makes night time sleep difficult.

Ramelteon is a melatonin receptor agonist approved for insomnia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman's The Pharmacological Basis of therapeutics 14th edition, Page no. 435

questions.text: Nikshay Poshan Yojana includes
questions.solution:
(a) 500 Rupees per month:

- Nikshay Poshan Yojana is a financial support scheme introduced by the Indian government under the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP). It provides a monthly financial support of 500 Rupees to TB patients during the course of their treatment. This financial assistance is aimed at ensuring better nutrition and adherence to treatment, especially for patients from economically disadvantaged backgrounds.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

(b) 500 Rupees per week:

- Providing 500 Rupees per week would be a significantly higher financial support than what Nikshay Poshan Yojana offers. The scheme specifically provides 500 Rupees per month, not per week.

(c) Mid-day meal daily:

- The provision of mid-day meals is a separate government program aimed at providing nutritious meals to school children to improve their nutritional status and encourage school attendance. It is not directly related to the Nikshay Poshan Yojana, which focuses specifically on financial assistance to TB patients.

(d) Nutritional dietary advice/counselling:

- While nutritional support and counseling may be important components of TB treatment and care, Nikshay Poshan Yojana primarily focuses on providing financial assistance to TB patients. While dietary advice and counseling may be provided as part of comprehensive TB care, it is not the primary component of the Nikshay Poshan Yojana.

In summary, Nikshay Poshan Yojana includes providing 500 Rupees per month as financial support to TB patients undergoing treatment. This assistance aims to improve nutritional intake and treatment adherence among TB patients, particularly those from economically disadvantaged backgrounds. Therefore, option (a) is the correct choice.

A 1-week-old infant male presents to you for his first visit. His mother is concerned because he sleeps a lot. Which of the following is the average amount of sleep per day experienced by infants in the first month of life?
questions.solution:
• The majority of a newborn's early days are spent sleeping. Total requirements for sleep are 16 hours/24 hours in the first month of life, with most of the sleeping hours concentrated at night.
  • Sleep requirements decline slowly over the first year. By the age of 9 months, the average infant sleeps 14 hours/day and by 3 years of age, most toddlers sleep 12 hours/day.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer has itchy erythematous papular lesions on face, neck, 'V' area of chest, dorsum of hands and forearms for 3 years. The most appropriate test to diagnose the condition would be
questions.solution:
• Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) is a diagnosis that encompasses dermatoses predominantly of exposed parts of body, which are caused by substances which when released into the air, settle on the exposed skin.
  • The most important allergens in hysterophorus responsible for allergic contact dermatitis are Sesquiterpene Lactones, present mainly in the oleoresin fraction of the plant.
  • In the classical airborne allergic contact dermatitis, there is involvement of exposed areas of face, "V" of neck, hands and forearms, "Wilkinson's triangle," both eyelids, nasolabial folds and under the chin.
  • Seen commonly in farmers living in rural areas.
  • Patch test reading is done at 48 and 96 hours.
  • Patch test should be used to diagnose any type of contact dermatitis which works on the principle of Delayed type of Hypersensitivity/Type-IV Hypersensitive Reaction.
  • The reading should be done in 48 and 96 hrs. Both readings should be taken. But the best reading should be at 96hrs. IgE levels maybe elevated but not enough to diagnose.
  • Treatment: Avoid triggers, Emoilents, Moisturisers, Steroid (Topical and oral). Azathioprine can be given as a long term drug unless contraindicated

questions.text: All of the following are seen in a case of autopsy of a young child who was a known case of acute rheumatic heart disease, except:
questions.solution:
During ACUTE Rheumatic fever:

  • Aschoff bodies:- Distinctive lesions in the heart - are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, occasional plasma cells, and plump activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. These macrophages have abundant cytoplasm and central round to ovoid nuclei (occasionally binucleate) in which the chromatin condenses into a central, slender, wavy ribbon (hence the designation "caterpillar cells"). (Choice B)
  • Pancarditis:- During acute RF, diffuse inflammation and Aschoff bodies may Be found in any of the three layers of the heart, resulting in pericarditis, myocarditis, or endocarditis. (Choice A)
  • MacCallum plaques :- Subendocardial lesions, perhaps exacerbated by regurgitant jets, can induce irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques, usually in the left atrium. (Choice D)
  • Verrucae :- Inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous chordae. Overlying these necrotic foci and along the lines of closure are small (1 to 2 mm) vegetations, called verrucae.

During CHRONIC RHEUMATIC FEVER:-

  • Leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and
  • Shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords (choice C)

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition) - Chapter 12, Pg no 561-562.

questions.text: For vaccine vial monitor identify the incorrect statement?
questions.solution:
VACCINE VIAL MONITORS

  • Vaccine vial monitors (VVMs) are the temperature monitoring devices that routinely accompany vaccines throughout the entire supply chain.
  • A VVM is a chemical indicator label attached to the vaccine container (vial, ampoule or dropper) by the vaccine As the container moves through the supply chain, the VVM records its cumulative heat exposure through a gradual change in colour.
  • If the colour of the inner square is the same colour or darker than the outer circle, the vaccine has been exposed to too much heat and should be discarded.
  • There are currently four types of VVM, chosen to match the heat sensitivity of the vaccine. These four types are WM2, VVM7, WM14 and WM30.
  • The VVM number is the time in days that it takes for the inner square to reach the colour indicating a discard point, if the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C.
  • The main purpose of VVMs is to ensure that heat damaged vaccines are not administered. The VVM status is also used to decide which vaccines can safely be kept after a cold chain break occurs thus minimizing unnecessary vaccine
  • In addition, VVM status helps the user to decide which vaccine should be used first - a batch of vaccine showing significant heat exposure should be distributed and used before a batch that shows lower heat exposure, even if its expiry date is longer. VVMs do not measure exposure to freezing temperature.
  • There are two different locations for VVMs and each is associated with specific guidance for handling opened multi-dose vials of vaccine :
    1. WHO-prequalified vaccines, where the WM, if attached, is on the label of the The vaccine vial, once opened, can be kept for subsequent immunization sessions up to 28 days, regardless of the formulation of the product {liquid or freeze-dried).
    2. WHO-prequalified vaccines where the VVM is attached in a location other than on the label (e.g., cap or neck of ampoule). In this instance, the vaccine vial, once opened, must be discarded at the end of the immunization session or within six hours of opening, whichever comes This is regardless of the formulation of the product (liquid or freeze-dried).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition

questions.text: A term infant is delivered vaginally to an 18-year-old prima gravida after an uncomplicated pregnancy. Mother presented with rupture of membranes and a low-grade fever. Labor and delivery proceeded rapidly, maternal antibiotics were not administered prior to delivery of the infant. At 30 hours of age the infant is mottled, not feeding well, and cries when handled. A lumbar puncture is performed and the spinal fluid reveals 660 WBC/mm3 and a CSF protein of 290 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely agent causing this infant's infection?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of neonatal meningitis is group B streptococcus (GBS).
  • Escherichia coli generally is the second leading cause.
  • Listeria is less frequent but not uncommon.
  • Hemophilus influenzae is an uncommon cause of meningitis during the first month of life.
  • GBS is usually vertically transmitted from the mother either at delivery or from ascending transmission after rupture of membranes. The risk for neonatal infection increases in the presence of prematurity, prolonged rupture of membranes, intrapartum fever, chorio- aminionitis, and maternal GBS bacteriuria. Vaginal colonization of GBS (or absence of colonization) may be transient, so screening cultures are not 100% predictive of status at delivery.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 1431

questions.text: Which of the following resembles erythroblastosis fetalis?
questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis Fetalis is haemolytic anaemia in the foetus caused by transplacental transmission maternal antibodies to foetal red blood cells.

  • Usually due to incompatibility between maternal and foetal blood group often Rh D antigen.
  • In these usually infant dies, kernicterus can occur, in this deposition of bilirubin in the brain, hearing loss, mental retardation can occur.

Cytomegalovirus infection resembles erythroblastosis fetalis.

  • Foetal abnormalities that can be seen in CMV are intracranial calcification, microcephaly, ventriculomegaly, lenticulostriate vasculopathy, occipital horn abnormality, echogenic bowel.
  • Intrauterine growth restriction, hepatomegaly, pericardial effusion and ascites.

questions.text: A patient presented with persecutory delusions and 3rd person auditory hallucinations and was diagnosed with Schizophrenia. He was prescribed Risperidone 2.5 mg to be taken daily. Next day, the came to casualty with persistent upward gaze for a few hours. What is the next step of management ?
questions.solution:
• Clinical presentations of acute dystonic reactions

Buccolingual Crisis
- trismus, risus sardonicus, dysarthria, dysphagia, grimacing, tongue protrusion

Oculogyric Crisis
- spasm of the extraocular muscles, most commonly deviated upward

Torticolic Crisis- abnormal asymmetric head or neck position.

  • Most common causative agents for acute dystonic reaction Antipsychotic and antiemetic agents
