questions.text: You are the attending physician for a newborn infant with hemolytic jaundice. The mother did not receive prenatal care with this pregnancy or her prior pregnancy. The direct Coombs test is positive. The mother's blood type is A- and the baby's blood type is O+. Her first baby did not have hemolytic jaundice. What is the most likely cause of the hemolytic jaundice?
questions.solution:
• Rh hemolytic disease rarely occurs in the first pregnancy, but transfusion of Rh+ blood into an Rh– mother sensitizes the mother resulting initially in production of IgM antibodies, followed by IgG antibody production.
  • Once a mother is sensitized, the following pregnancies result in hemolytic disease. Sensitization is prevented by injection of anti-D gamma globulin at 28 week's gestation and immediately after delivery. The incidence of Rh incompatibility is 11/10,000 total births.
  • Hereditary spherocytosis and congenital infections, causing hemolytic disease, are distinguished by negative Coombs testing as well as other clinical characteristic exam findings or peripheral smear findings.
  • ABO incompatibility may occur in the first pregnancy. Subsequent pregnancies are not more severely affected. It would not occur when the fetus is blood type O.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 967

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Budd Chiari syndrome?
questions.solution:
BUDD-CHIARI SYNDROME

  • The obstruction of major hepatic veins produces liver enlargement, pain, and ascites, a condition known as Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • Obstruction of a single main hepatic vein by thrombosis is clinically silent.
  • Hepatic vein thrombosis is associated with:
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasms such as Polycythemia vera
  • Inherited disorders of coagulation
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome,
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria and
  • Intraabdominal cancers, particularly hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • In pregnancy or with oral contraceptive use, it occurs through interaction with an underlying thrombophilic disorder.
  • Grossly, the liver is swollen and red-purple and has a tense capsule. There may be areas of hemorrhagic collapse alternating with preserved or regenerating parenchyma, with the patterns being dependent on which small and large hepatic veins are obstructed.
  • Microscopically, the affected hepatic parenchyma reveals severe centrilobular congestion and necrosis. Pericentral/sinusoidal fibrosis develops in instances in which thrombosis develops more slowly. The major veins contain thrombi showing various degrees of organization.

Reference: Robbins Pathologic Basis Of Disease (10th edition)- Chapter 18, Pg no 862.

questions.text: Diagnostic test for neurosyphilis?
questions.solution:
Neurosyphilis

An infection that affects the coverings of the brain, the brain itself and spinal cord. It occurs in people with syphilis, especially if their condition is left untreated.

Symptoms:

  • Abnormal walk (Gait), unable to walk.
  • Numbness in the toes, feet or legs.
  • Problem with thinking, poor concentration
  • Mental problem, depression or irritability
  • Headache, seizure, stiff neck
  • Loss of bladder control
  • Tremor weakness.

Lab diagnosis:

  • by CSF VDRL, VDRL is more specific for neurosyphilis.
  • CSF FTAABS
  • CSF RPRm
  • CSF TPI can be done but they are less sensitive and specific than VDRL.

Reference:Principles of Internal Medicine, Harrison's 19th edition page 1385

questions.text: All the following methods are anti-larval except
questions.solution:
D) Pyrethrum: Pyrethrum is a natural insecticide derived from the flowers of certain species of chrysanthemum. While pyrethrum is highly effective against adult mosquitoes and other insects, it is not typically used to target mosquito larvae. Pyrethrum primarily acts as a contact insecticide, affecting insects upon direct contact with the substance. It is less effective in water environments where mosquito larvae reside. Therefore, pyrethrum is not considered an anti-larval method but rather an adulticidal or insecticidal method.

Why the other options are not suitable:

A) Intermittent irrigation: Intermittent irrigation involves alternating periods of flooding and drying in agricultural fields to disrupt the breeding sites of mosquitoes. This method is effective in controlling mosquito larvae because it disrupts their habitat and prevents them from completing their life cycle. Therefore, intermittent irrigation is considered an anti-larval method.

B) Paris green: Paris green is a toxic substance containing copper (II) acetate and arsenic (III) acetate. It has been historically used as an insecticide, including for controlling mosquito larvae. Paris green works by poisoning the larvae when they come into contact with the treated water. Therefore, Paris green is also an effective anti-larval method.

C) Gambusia affinis: Gambusia affinis, commonly known as the western mosquitofish, is a species of fish that feeds on mosquito larvae. Introducing Gambusia affinis into water bodies containing mosquito larvae can significantly reduce mosquito populations as the fish consume the larvae. Therefore, Gambusia affinis is considered an anti-larval method.

In summary, option D is the correct answer because pyrethrum is not an anti-larval method, unlike the other options which are all effective in controlling mosquito larvae

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy comes with complaints of severe headache and shortness of breath. The X-ray chest is as follows. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Rib notching refers to deformation of the superior or inferior surface of the rib. It can affect a single rib (from trauma or solitary masses e.g. schwannoma) or can affect multiple ribs.
  • Differential diagnosis: The differentials differ according to whether it is the superior or inferior surface that is notched.
  • Superior rib notching:
    • abnormal osteoblastic activity
      • osteogenesis imperfecta
    • connective tissue diseases
      • rheumatoid arthritis
      • systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
      • Marfan syndrome
      • Sjogren syndrome
      • scleroderma 3
      • local pressure
      • abnormal osteoclastic activity
      • hyperparathyroidism
    • miscellaneous:
      • neurofibromatosis type 1
      • restrictive lung disease
      • poliomyelitis
      • progeria
      • abnormal muscle pull
  • Inferior rib notching: (as seen in X ray)
    • enlarged collateral vessels
      • coarctationof the aorta (Roesler sign)
      • interrupted aortic arch
      • subclavian artery obstruction
      • Takayasu disease
      • Blalock-Taussig shunt: involves only upper two rib spaces
      • arteriovenous malformation (AVM) of the chest wall
        • superior vena cava obstruction with enlarged venous collaterals
        • pulmonary AVM
        • tetralogy of Fallot
      • neurogenic tumors
      • schwannoma (usually single)
      • neurofibromatosis type 1 (rarely can be superior if neurofibroma is very large)
    • Superior and inferior rib notching:
      • hyperparathyroidism
      • neurofibromatosis type 1

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 2390

questions.text: During a disaster, rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of severity of their injuries and likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention is part of
questions.solution:
Triage is the process of rapidly assessing and prioritizing the medical treatment of individuals affected by a disaster based on the severity of their injuries or medical conditions and the likelihood of their survival with prompt medical intervention. It aims to allocate limited medical resources efficiently to maximize the number of lives saved. Triage helps medical personnel to identify and prioritize those who require immediate medical attention, those who can wait for treatment, and those who are beyond help.

Explanation for why the other options are not correct:

a. Search, Rescue, and First Aid:

  • While search, rescue, and first aid are critical components of disaster response, they primarily involve locating and rescuing survivors, providing immediate medical assistance, and stabilizing injured individuals before they receive further medical treatment. Triage occurs after the initial rescue phase, once injured individuals have been located and are receiving first aid.

b. Tagging:

  • Tagging refers to the process of labelling or marking individuals during triage to indicate their priority for medical treatment. Tagging is a specific step within the triage process and is used to ensure that medical resources are allocated appropriately based on the severity of injuries or medical conditions.

c. Disaster mitigation:

  • Disaster mitigation involves activities undertaken before a disaster occurs to reduce its impact and minimize its effects on communities and infrastructure. This includes measures such as risk assessment, hazard identification, and the implementation of strategies to prevent or lessen the severity of disasters. Triage, on the other hand, occurs during the response phase of a disaster and focuses on immediate medical care for the injured.

questions.text: A 10-day old baby comes with following skin lesions with slight hyperpigmentation at the base. He is otherwise healthy and feeding well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• TNPM has 3 types of lesions: (1) evanescent superficial pustules, (2) ruptured pustules with a collarette of fine scale, at times with a central hyperpigmented macule, and (3) hyperpigmented macules.
  • Lesions are present at birth, and 1 or all types of lesions may be found in a profuse or sparse distribution. Pustules represent the early phase of the disorder, and macules, the late phase.
  • The pustular phase rarely lasts more than 2-3 days; hyperpigmented macules may persist for as long as 3 mo. Sites of predilection are the anterior neck, forehead, and lower back, although the scalp, trunk, limbs, palms, and soles may be affected.
  • Erythema toxicum, the lesions are firm, yellow-white, 1-2 mm papules or pustules with a surrounding erythematous flare.
  • Milia, the lesion is a firm cyst, 1-2 mm in diameter, and pearly, opalescent white.
  • SSSS has fever with toxemia. Child will be sick.

Reference: Nelson textbook of pediatrics, 21st ed., pg. 3455

questions.text: All the following are quantitative variables except
questions.solution:
c. Gender: Gender is not a quantitative variable; instead, it is a categorical or qualitative variable. Gender represents a non-numerical attribute or characteristic that categorizes individuals into distinct groups (e.g., male, female, or non-binary). Unlike quantitative variables, which involve numerical measurements, categorical variables involve categories or labels that cannot be quantified in the same way as numerical variables.

Explanation why the other options are not correct:

a. Serum cholesterol: Serum cholesterol is a quantitative variable because it represents a measurable quantity or amount, typically expressed in numerical values (e.g., milligrams per decilitre). It can be directly measured using laboratory tests, making it a quantitative variable.

b. Weight: Weight is also a quantitative variable because it represents a measurable quantity or amount of mass, typically expressed in numerical values (e.g., kilograms or pounds). Weight can be directly measured using scales, making it a quantitative variable.

d. Celsius temperature scales: Celsius temperature scales represent quantitative variables because they measure temperature on a numerical scale. Temperature values in Celsius degrees are quantitative measurements that can be directly measured using thermometers and are expressed in numerical values.

In summary, serum cholesterol, weight, and Celsius temperature scales are all examples of quantitative variables because they involve numerical measurements, whereas gender is a categorical variable because it involves non-numerical categories or labels.

questions.text: A patient presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. His GCS was 3. CT Brain showed a normal study. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Most DAIs are caused by high-velocity motor vehicle collisions generated by sudden changes in acceleration/deceleration
  • The cortex moves at a different speed relative to underlying deep brain structures (white matter, deep gray nuclei)
  • This results in axonal stretching, especially where brain tissues of different density intersect, i.e., the gray-white matter interface.
  • One of the most striking features of DAI is the discrepancy between clinical symptoms and imaging findings.

questions.text: Which is the investigation of choice in breast of a woman with implants?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance imaging

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the breast is useful in a number of settings:

  • to distinguish scar from recurrence in women who have had previous breast conservation therapy for cancer (although it is less accurate within 9 months of radiotherapy because of abnormal enhancement);
  • to assess multifocality and multicentricity in lobular cancer and to assess the extent of high-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). It is less useful in low-grade DCIS;
  • it is the best imaging modality for the breasts of women with implants;
  • as a screening tool in high-risk women (because of family history).
  • Although biopsies can be performed with MRI guidance, this is complicated by the configuration of the imaging system.
  • With improved ultrasound equipment, an MRI-detected lesion can often be found on a second-look ultrasound and biopsied using this modality.

Reference: Bailey & Love's short practice of surgery, chapter: 58, Edition: 28th, Pg: 916-917

questions.text: Quarantine was originally introduced as a protection against
questions.solution:
Quarantine, as a public health measure, was originally introduced as a protection against the spread of infectious diseases, particularly the plague. The practice of quarantine dates back to ancient times when communities would isolate individuals suspected of having contagious diseases to prevent the spread of illness to others. The term "quarantine" itself is derived from the Italian word "quaranta giorni," meaning "forty days," which refers to the period of isolation typically imposed on ships and individuals during the Black Death pandemic in the 14th century.

Explanation for why not the other options:

b. TB (Tuberculosis):

  • While tuberculosis is a contagious bacterial infection that can be transmitted through the air, quarantine measures were not originally introduced specifically for TB. However, isolation and quarantine may be used in modern public health practices to prevent the spread of TB in certain circumstances.

c. AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome):

  • Quarantine was not introduced specifically as a protection against AIDS. AIDS is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which primarily spreads through unprotected sexual contact, contaminated blood transfusions, and sharing of needles among intravenous drug users. Quarantine measures are not typically employed to control the spread of HIV/AIDS due to its mode of transmission.

d. Malaria:

  • Quarantine was not introduced specifically as a protection against malaria. Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by parasites of the Plasmodium genus. While efforts to control malaria often involve measures to prevent mosquito bites and reduce transmission, quarantine is not a primary strategy for malaria prevention.

questions.text: Most comprehensive indicator of Cost-Effective analysis is
questions.solution:
QALYs gained (c): Quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) gained is considered the most comprehensive indicator in cost-effectiveness analysis. QALYs combine both the quantity and quality of life gained from an intervention into a single measure. It accounts for changes in health-related quality of life by weighting each year of life gained by a utility value representing the individual's health status. QALYs allow decision-makers to compare the cost-effectiveness of interventions across different health conditions and outcomes, taking into account both the length and quality of life.

Explanation for why not the other options:

  • No. of life years gained (a): While the number of life years gained is an important outcome measure, it does not fully capture the quality of life experienced by individuals. It focuses solely on the quantity of life gained without considering the impact on the quality of life.
  • No. of heart attacks avoided (b): This indicator is specific to a particular health outcome (heart attacks) and does not account for the overall impact on health-related quality of life or consider other health conditions and outcomes.
  • Cost per life year gained (d): Cost per life year gained is a common metric used in cost-effectiveness analysis, but it only considers the cost-effectiveness of interventions in terms of extending life expectancy. It does not directly account for the quality of life experienced by individuals during those additional years.

Therefore, option (c) is the most appropriate choice as it provides a comprehensive measure of the impact of interventions on individuals' health-related quality of life, considering both longevity and well-being.

questions.text: N-acetyl-p- benzoquinoneimine causes hepatic necrosis in poisoning with ?
questions.solution:
MECHANISM OF TOXICITY


  • Therapeutic dose : 90% of acetaminophen is metabolized in liver to sulfate and glucuronide conjugates excreted in urine
  • In the remaining 10%, 5% is excreted unchanged in urine 5% is metabolized via hepatic cytochrome P450 to NAPQI (N-acetyl p- benzoquinoneimine) - hepatotoxic
  • With normal doses, NAPQI is rapidly conjugated to hepatic glutathione, forming nontoxic cysteine and mercaptate compounds that are excreted in the urine
  • With toxic doses, the sulfate and glucuronide pathways become saturated, resulting in an increased fraction of acetaminophen being metabolized by cytochrome P450 enzymes. Once glutathione stores are depleted, NAPQI begins to accumulate - hepatotoxicity

questions.text: A patient presented with a painful rash as is shown in image since the past 2 days. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Varicella-zoster virus infection causes two distinct diseases
  • Primary infection with VZV results in varicella (chickenpox), characterized by vesicular lesions in different stages of development on the face, trunk, and extremities
  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, results from reactivation of latent VZV infection within the sensory ganglia
  • The presenting clinical manifestations of herpes zoster are usually characterized by rash and acute neuritis
  • The thoracic and lumbar dermatomes are the most commonly involved sites of herpes zoster
  • Immunocompromised hosts are at risk for cutaneous and visceral dissemination
